en: From its majestic viewpoint, one can see the Mont Ventoux and the Alpilles. On the ancient Oppidum dominating the village of Chusclan, stand the ruins of the Château de Gicon. From the top of its wooded plateau, the keep of the castle dominates the Rhône and its valley. A footpath, leading through the vineyards and the forest and accessible to all levels of hikers, allows you to reach it by passing by the old chapel dedicated to Sainte Madeleine built in the 13th century by the Carthusian monks of Valbonne. Medieval fortress. Watchtower, dungeon, fortress, the castle took shape during the Middle Ages, when it became a stronghold due to its position at the crossroads of four provinces. During his crusade to Tunis, in 1248, Louis IX would have stopped at Gicon. The castle was bought in 1973 by the wine growers of Chusclan who are today the owners. Thanks to them, the ruins of Gicon have been restored and are open to the public. They produce a special vintage "Château de Gicon" on the 12 hectares of the former seigniorial vineyard. Below the remains of the Roman villa, hidden by the vegetation, is a natural cave where the Celts practiced their solar cult. Itinerary :From the chapel of Maransan (hamlet of Carmignan), continue on the asphalt road towards Carmignan for 300 m, until you reach a post marked Bruguier (big oak). Here, turn left and directly right on the DFCI. When you reach the post indicating côte 105, turn left into the wood. At the next crossroads, turn left and take the road that runs along the gas pipeline for 200 m. At the crossroads, turn right and follow the track to the foot of the castle of Gicon. Go up on the left to reach the cistern. Here, the castle is indicated. Plan to leave one hour before sunrise.
fr: Depuis son majestueux belvédère, on distingue le Mont-Ventoux et les Alpilles.Sur l’ancien Oppidum dominant le village de Chusclan, se dressent les ruines du Château de Gicon. Du haut de son plateau boisé, le donjon du Château domine le Rhône et sa vallée. Un sentier pédestre, cheminant au milieu des vignes et de la forêt et accessible à tous niveau de randonneurs, permet d’y accéder en passant par l’ancienne chapelle dédiée à Sainte Madeleine construite au 13ème siècle par les Chartreux de Valbonne. Forteresse médiévale. Tour de guet, donjon, forteresse, le château prend forme au cours du Moyen-Âge, où il sera une place forte de par sa position à la croisée de quatre provinces.Lors de sa croisade vers Tunis, en 1248, Louis IX aurait fait halte à Gicon. Le château a été racheté en 1973 par les vignerons de Chusclan qui en sont aujourd’hui les propriétaires. Grâce à eux, les ruines de Gicon ont pu être restaurées et accueillent du public. Ils produisent une cuvée spéciale "Château de Gicon" sur les 12 hectares de l’ancien vignoble seigneurial. En contrebas des vestiges de la villa romaine, masquée par la végétation, se trouve une grotte naturelle où les Celtes pratiquaient leur culte solaire. Itinéraire :Au départ de la chapelle de Maransan (hameau de Carmignan), continuer sur le chemin goudronné en direction de Carmignan sur 300 m, jusqu’au poteau où il est indiqué Bruguier (gros chêne). Ici, prendre à gauche et directement à droite sur la DFCI. Arrivé au poteau qui indique côte 105, prendre à gauche dans le bois. Au prochain carrefour, tourner à gauche et emprunter la route qui longe le gazoduc sur 200 m. Au carrefour, tourner à droite et suivre la piste jusqu’au pied du château de Gicon. Monter par la gauche pour arriver à la citerne. Ici, le château est indiqué. Prévoir de partir une heure avant le lever de soleil.

en:
From its majestic belvedere, one can see the Mont Ventoux and the Alpilles.
On the ancient Oppidum dominating the village of Chusclan, stand the ruins of the Château de Gicon
From the top of its wooded plateau, the keep of the castle dominates the Rhône and its valley
A footpath, leading through the vineyards and the forest and accessible to all levels of hikers, allows you to reach it by passing by the old chapel dedicated to Sainte Madeleine built in the 13th century by the Carthusian monks of Valbonne. Watchtower, dungeon, fortress, the castle takes shape during the Middle Ages, where it will be a stronghold by its position at the crossroads of four provinces.during his crusade to Tunis, in 1248, Louis IX would have stopped in Gicon

The castle was bought in 1973 by the wine growers of Chusclan who are today the owners
Thanks to them, the ruins of Gicon have been restored and are open to the public
They produce a special vintage "Château de Gicon" on the 12 hectares of the former seigniorial vineyard
Below the remains of the Roman villa, hidden by vegetation, is a natural cave where the Celts practiced their solar cult
Itinerary:
From the chapel of Maransan (hamlet of Carmignan), continue on the tarred road towards Carmignan for 300 m, until the post where it says Bruguier (big oak). Here, turn left and directly right on the DFCI
When you reach the post indicating côte 105, turn left into the wood
At the next crossroads, turn left and take the road that runs along the gas pipeline for 200 m
At the crossroads, turn right and follow the track to the foot of the castle of Gicon
Go up on the left to reach the cistern. Here, the castle is indicated. Plan to leave one hour before sunrise.
